section.title: Comparative & superlative adjectives and adverbs
section.sectiontitle: Add -er and -est to form the comparatives and superlatives of one-syllable adjectives and adverbs, two-syllable adjectives and adverbs ending in -y.
section.text1a: My younger sister can run a lot faster than I can.
section.sectiontitle2: Use more and most to form the comparatives and superlatives of adjectives and adverbs with two or more-syllables.
section.text3a: I'd really like to speak English more fluently.
section.text4a: That was the most interesting film I've seen in a long time.

section.title: Comparative & superlative adjectives and adverbs
section.sectiontitle: You can also use (not) as ... as to make comparisons.
section.text1a: This beach is as beautiful as I remember it.
section.text2a: I can't play the piano as well as Michael. He's brilliant.

section.title: Comparative & superlative adjectives and adverbs
section.sectiontitle: Some common irregular forms of comparative and superlative adjectives and adverbs are: good / well > better > the best , bad / badly > worse > the worst, much > more > most, far> further> the furthest and little > less > least.
section.text1a: The dessert was better than the main course.
section.text2a: The station was further away than I expected.
section.sectiontitle2: We can't use very to modify comparatives, but for a small difference we can use a bit, a little, or slightly. For a larger difference we can use far, much, very much, a lot or quite a lot.
section.text3a: The German car was much more expensive.
section.text4a: I'm feeling quite a lot better today.
